prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for refusing to buy family members Christmas gifts after receiving a $400 gift card. 

First, the situation: The author got a gift card, told their sister about it, and then their mom found out. The mom and sister then started pressuring the author to buy gifts for them and extended family, including cousins. The author felt this pressure was obnoxious, especially since they're 15, not used to having a lot of money, and wanted to spend the gift card on themselves. They ended up not buying gifts and got into an argument with their mom.

Now, considering the context. The author is a teenager, which is a key point. At 15, they're still learning about money management and personal boundaries. The mom might see it as a responsibility to share the gift card with family, especially during a holiday. However, the mom's approach—bursting into the room, the obnoxious comments, and the pressure—could have felt very controlling or greedy to the author. The fact that the author had to work up the nerve to say no after being pressured by both the sister and mom suggests that the pressure was significant. 

Also, the cousins are young (6 and 2), so the expectation to buy thoughtful, non-cheap gifts for them might be unreasonable. The author might feel that this is an unnecessary expense, especially if they don't see these cousins often. The mom's reaction, including guilt-tripping and an argument, indicates that communication was a problem.

From a moral standpoint, whether the author is in the wrong depends on cultural expectations and family norms. In some families, sharing gifts or treating family members during Christmas is a given. However, the author is using their own money (even if it's a gift card) and has the right to decide how to spend it. The mom's overreaction and the pressure might have crossed a line, leading the author to feel justified in their decision.

But there's also the argument that Christmas is a time for giving, and the author might be seen as selfish for not sharing. However, considering the circumstances—being a teenager, the pressure from family, and the mom's behavior—it's a grey area. The key points are the mom's overstepping and the author's right to their own money. 

So, taking into account the age, the pressure tactics, and the unreasonableness of the expectations (especially for young cousins), it's more about the mom's approach being wrong. The author isn't necessarily in the wrong for setting a boundary. Therefore, the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
